8/8
this is the simplest and easiest solution. it is the only solution that leads to: (1) profits in private enterprise; (2) new tax revenues for governments; and (3) reducing or eliminating poachers' economic incentives to kill rhinos.

7/8
furthermore, the governments in these countries would gain a source of tax revenues in regulating the trade - instead of saving rhinos being a huge financial burden, it becomes a source of income.  that money could be used to fund wild rhino conservation efforts as well.

6/8
as the legal supply of rhino horns grows to meet the global demand, the price would come down. poachers' incentive to kill rhinos - wild or privately owned - would be dramatically reduced or eliminated. they wouldn't be able to compete with legal enterprise.

5/8
if the trade were legalized, investors would step in to fund rhino ranches like john hume's. the population would grow quickly and significantly - mostly on private ranches.

3/8
rhino horns regenerate - they grow back. the only reason #poachers kill them is because it's the safest and easiest way for someone with little money (only afford to buy a gun) to harvest and sell on the black market.

the reality is that rhino poaching is so extreme that some species may be gone - extinct - in 10 years. there are more than 3 african rhinos a day brutally killed for their horns, which is literally the same stuff as your *toenails*. it is not medicine. it is not an aphrodisiac.
